characters: AT THE BASE OF THE DRIVEWAY/ON THE SIDEWALK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, it’s Fall. Not in a cozy, peaceful way. In that slush miserable Midwest way. Strong winds bend the trees of Lakeshore Drive. Grey rain drips from the Magnificent Mil storefronts to the street signs of the suburbs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights turn on at the Portokalos house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large old black Cadillac backs down the driveway of the Corinthian-columned home. It drives at a wrong angle. Stops. Drives forward, corrects. Backs out again. Correct again. Backs out. The car drives ten feet and stops at the very next home. SFX: HONKING. That house door opens.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR/MILLER HOUSE
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP: A smudged “HAPPINESS IS BEING GREEK” Greek flag cover on an OPA! license plate. PAN UP.... INT. GUS’S CADILLAC/MILLER HOUSE - DAY, CONTINUOUS SFX: Car door closing. Through the windshield, in the passenger seat, TOULA PORTOKALOS, 40's, is burrowed in a scarf, her glasses fog with every breath. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS PORTOKALOS, 70's, looks to his right, concerned. He i about to put the car in gear, but then:

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You better get married, you're starting to look old. Startled, Toula looks up, realizes her dad is not talking her. In fact, he is looking in the rear-view mirror, at t back seat. At Toula’s daughter.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Dad!! You can’t say that to her! PARIS, Gus’s 17 year old granddaughter, pops forward, loo at him with horror and dismay.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Pappou!! Gus shrugs, puts the car in gear. Toula, not looking together this morning, or ever, shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, that’s a family tradition. My dad used to say that to me and now he just said it to my daughter. She’s 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT: The car, in front of the modest Miller home, w is beside the Portokalos home, now drives....

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My family worries about each other. We're close. Extremely close. +... ten feet, stops at the very next house. This house i decorated with all things Greek, complete with a Partheno Marbles door frame. Toula’s brother, NICK PORTOKALOS, 40, waves from the wind

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We see no difference between hugging and suffocation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus honks. (Annoyed every morning, NEIGHBORS glare out windows. )

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/NICK’S HOUSE - DAY, CONTINUOUS Gus wags a finger.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Toula, find your daughter a Greek boyfriend before she does what you did.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: What the --

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Married a Xeno --

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: My husband --

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Not Greek, a Xeno --

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: How can you say that-- Paris leans forward, angry at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Stop. Chagrined, Toula turns and looks out the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do I speak for all mothers of teens when I ask, does it ever get better? Gus lowers Toula’s window, cold wind and leaves hit her i the face.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. NICK’S HOUSE - DAY, CONTINUOUS Nick’s wife, ILARIA, 30's, pregnant, waves as her TWIN BO 4, pull MARIA PORTOKALOS, 70's, holding the “leashes” of their harness backpacks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (yells) Gus, I put your pills by your coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... Nick, a parka over a robe, runs out with COSTA, 9.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/NICK’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Gus is always thrilled at the sight of his son.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Nicko! Nick leans in the passenger window, holds up Costa’s proj on, of course, Greece.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. Dad, pop the trunk, I’m freezing my ‘nads off. Costa climbs over Paris, squishes too close, wags a finge like an old Greek man.

dialogues.speaker: COSTA
dialogues.text: Too much makeup. Toula sees Paris is annoyed being schooled by a ‘tween.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Costa, did you finish drawing Alexander the Great?

dialogues.speaker: COSTA
dialogues.text: (proudly) Uh huh. And I sculpted a Parthenon out of soap. Costa holds up a crudely carved blob. And a typed page.

dialogues.speaker: COSTA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no, spell-check corrected Spanakopita to Spina Bifida. Gus lowers the back window, Nick leans in to kiss Costa, giggles and kisses him back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ah, kisses from your child. That’s over. Impatient to go, Gus points to a house, and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. ATHENA’S HOUSE/STREET - DAY, CONTINUOUS A Greek flag waves from a post, and a la the islands, the house is whitewashed with a bright blue dome roof. Holdin her BABY SON, ATHENA, late 40’s, and her husband YIANNI, 40's, appear.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My sister did it right. Just as her sons became possessed by the teen wolf hormones, she’d just pop out another one. Gus honks hello. Athena yells back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Move it, Aristotle!! Athena hands the baby to Yianni, steps out on a Mykonos- shaped welcome mat -- it plays the Greek National Anthem. ARISTOTLE, 9, runs out and by Athena.

dialogues.speaker: YIANNI
dialogues.text: (yells) Put on your hat!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/ATHENA’S HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Aristotle puts on his hat, crawls over Paris, squishes between her and Costa.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Paris, come by the restaurant some time.

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOTLE
dialogues.text: You should butter the garlic bread.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Can’t wait. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: (not getting it) Yeah, it’s fun. Athena licks her thumb, wipes food off Aristotle’s cheek. Then tries to do the same to Paris’s mascara.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Toula, you seen these eyes? You and Ian better fix that.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: (nope) Yep.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Okay bye! Gus drives as Athena yells out.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: After school you have hockey! Your brothers are coming so make sure you score! Gus drives off as Aristotle blows kisses to his mom.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You'll score, the Greeks invented hockey. Paris eye rolls in the back, Toula eye rolls in the front But Costa and Aristotle vehemently nod.

dialogues.speaker: COSTA
dialogues.text: Yes, because what do you play hockey on? Ice.

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOTLE
dialogues.text: What is the Greek word for ice. Payo.

dialogues.speaker: COSTA
dialogues.text: Payo, puck, there you go.

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOTLE
dialogues.text: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: There you go.... Paris and Toula scowl out the windows of the car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NOSY/CRANKY NEIGHBOR, MRS. WHITE, 60’s, walks her dog grimaces as the Cadillac passes her. Gus good-naturedly honks hello. Mrs. White jumps, then swears under her brea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus’s Cadillac drives.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Now give me a word, any word and I will show you how the root of that word is Greek--

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOTLE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Facebook!

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Greeks invented Facebook. We called it the telephone. Gus’s car pulls up. The boys head to the lower school. To watches Paris get out. Of course, Gus has one more nugget wisdom:

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Paris, keep your eyeballs open now for a nice Greek boy. Make babies, don’t waste your eggs. Toula winces. Paris can barely contain her revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Outstanding. Paris turns to the high school. Suddenly, Toula leaps from the car, grabs Paris. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: (blurts, loud and fast) Paris, Pappou didn’t mean to say anything hurtful, you’re beautiful, so beautiful, of course you don’t look old, he just says stuff like that, to, well, to me too, you don’t need a boyfriend, you don’t have to get married or have babies- Paris side-eyes the ever-present school loudmouth TOMMY, the COOL STUDENTS, including TIAHN, CLIFFORD, all 17. And, BENNETT, 17. Bennett. Toula doesn’t see the effect he has on Paris. Paris turns to glare at Toula.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (teeth gritted, sotto) Mother. Toula stops talking, stares at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When did my name change from--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARIS, 4, runs TO CAMERA:

dialogues.speaker: PARIS, (AT FOUR)
dialogues.text: Mommy!!!

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (furious ) Mother! ! Toula realizes she is holding Paris’s face. She drops her hands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris turns, walks past GROUPS OF TEENS. She is alone.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Ooh, drama. Toula blinks, looks up at: A banner hangs: COLLEGE FAIR TONIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The downtown Loop in the distance, the Cadillac drives through Greek Town.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/CHICAGO STREETS, (THE PRESENT)
dialogues.text: Gus drives, as Toula thinks.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I guess when my daughter started to pull away, I should have stepped back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PACKED volleyball game. Paris is a Line Judge. Wearing a PARENT VOLUNTEER sticker, Toula works the SNACKS TABLE on side.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But I stayed too close. I kept volunteering at her school. I wanted her to think I was cool again. Toula keeps waving to Paris, who wishes she would go away Then, a volleyball smacks Toula in the head. She drops. T GYM of PEOPLE sucks in air. Paris cringes at the attentio Toula is on the ground. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then I remembered I’ve never been cool. MARGE and EDIE, 40's, the overbearing Volunteer Moms, smi into their hands. STUDENTS, including Tommy, are quietly giggling. Then-

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Here comes the principal. The principal is backlit. It’s IAN MILLER, 40's, and even though he looks worn down by the teen years, he is handso

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My husband has always been cool. He just has it. And he always knows what to say. Ian leans in.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You okay, babe? Toula sits up, nods, sees: Paris looks at her with disdai

dialogues.speaker: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/CHICAGO STREETS
dialogues.text: Remembering this, Toula winces.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just when my daughter doesn’t want me around anymore, my parents need me more than ever. Gus, driving, nods off. Toula nudges his chin, he wakes u Toula sees they pass the SENIORS’ REHAB CENTER.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I take them to get groceries, to their doctors, and to Physical Therapy. Toula waits: through the glass, Gus does hip therapy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toula blows off dust from a peanuts bowl. Eats some. The receptionist, DOMINIQUE, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: DOMINIQUE
dialogues.text: The old guys suck the chocolate off those nuts. Toula spits nuts.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/OLYMPIC TRAVEL
dialogues.text: Gus drives past closed-down buildings, one with two tatte signs: OLYMPIC DRY CLEANING, and OLYMPIC TRAVEL AGENCY. Toula sees the sign.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I used to love being a travel agent. But in a tight economy the first things to go are luxuries like travel and dry cleaning.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/DANCING ZORBA’S - DAY The car pulls up to the family restaurant, DANCING ZORBA’

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Luckily, people still eat. Toula gets out, then helps her dad as he slowly gets hims out. Toula pulls a walking cane from the car. Gus looks around to be sure no one sees this, reluctantly takes it. Toula holds his arm as they walk. Gus slips, bumps into Toula, knocking off her glasses. Gus steps, accidentally crunching them to bits.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DANCING ZORBA’S - DAY Toula now squints, flips on the lights, hangs up their co Gus, exhausted already, limps to the corner booth. Toula hangs a worn sign in the window: WE NOW CATER, TOO! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My sister and brother have small children, so I help at the restaurant. It’s what nice Greek girls do. Toula puts on a mud-brown Seating Hostess jacket. Toula walks past a pie case filled with mini-bundt cakes, each with a Fall-colored orange or cranberry gerbera in i center.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Families that are close like mine, we make it through bad economies, wars and sickness because we stick together... Toula goes to a drawer, finds a strip of empty disposable contact lenses. She remembers something, and rummages to find a pair of glasses. They’re ugly and they were once hers. She puts them on. Toula looks as downcast and frumpy as she once did.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: .-.- but some of us just get stuck. Toula looks out the window. Cars and PEOPLE pass her by. day is as bleak as her mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the exact same stance as her mother Toula, Paris stand looking out the window. SMALL GROUPS OF STUDENTS huddle at lockers. Paris is alon She turns and heads into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris takes a book from a bookshelf -- Ian walks up.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hey Paris -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Do not talk to me. People think I'm a narc.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I -- shouldn’t you be in class?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: You track me all day! Mom is needy, Pappou wants to marry me off, Yiayia constantly tells me to never, ever let a boy touch my poulaki because once he feels it, he wants it. Ugh, this family! STUDENTS look over at the voices from the bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Save it for the therapist’s couch. Riiiiiight? He goes for a high five which no one returns.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Paris, your mom once felt the same way about being Greek--

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Dad, that’s obtuse, why would I have an issue being Greek? Paris points behind her to 5 cheerful posters declaring upcoming meetings: Syrian Club!, Korean Club, Greek Club! Gay & Lesbian Club!, Handi-Capable Club!

dialogues.speaker: PARIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t take that everyone is always in my business! Give me some air. I’m not a kid, I can be late to a class, there won’t be a spasmodic catastrophic ripple in the space-time continuum. And yes, four of those words are Greek. Paris storms away, Ian looks worn out.

dialogues.speaker: BANNER
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PARENTS and STUDENTS enter the gym.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOTHS line the walls. Fresh-faced REPS, from colleges fr Harvard to Phoenix University, talk to STUDENTS and PAREN Slapping on a PARENT VOLUNTEER sticker, Toula looks for I sees those overbearing moms, Marge and Edie, and ducks ba They intercept her.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Hey, hi! Marge and Edie click their pens, tap their clipboards.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Where were you when we set up?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Sorry, my pipes froze --

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: And decorated the gym --

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I had to plunge the sink -- They stare her down, clicking their pens.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: You’re on Clean-Up. Marge hands Toula a garbage can, they leave as Ian walks

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hi. Having been married 17 years, they barely look at each ot

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Hi. Ian takes the garbage can from Toula, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You can say no to them. Toula laughs ruefully. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Babe, it’s been a long time since those two made fun of your lunch -- Toula winces, remembering.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: They called it moose-caca. Ian nods, he’s heard it before. Toula sees and points to Paris:

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: There’s Paris .... Paris moves to the next booth: NORTHWESTERN UNIVERSITY.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, if she goes to Northwestern, she'll stay in Chicago!

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Please, oh please. Should we go over there?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Nuh uh. Ian gently pulls Toula back.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: There she is! Toula’s face freezes. Did she just hear her mother?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: No no. THE PORTOKALOS FAMILY (Gus, Maria, UNCLE TAKI, ANGELO, NI her HUSBAND and TWO SONS, 20's, Nick, Costa, Athena, Aristotle in a pee-wee hockey jersey carried on the shoul of FOUR BROTHERS, ages 18 to 27, plus SEVERAL MALE COUSIN comes thundering down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Did you invite the family?! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toula gasps, realizes she made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I told my mom. Maria pounces on horrified Paris.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Be a dental hygienist! A mother working two days a week, perfect. Nikki pulls a COMB from her Hairdressers’s work smock.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Paris, be a hairdresser like me. As the family gives their opinions to Paris, Gus nudges I points to all the BOYS in the family.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Ian, look, everyone has boys. You, one girl. Vegetarian. Slow sperms. Maria’s cell rings.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: It’s Thea Voula on The Facetimes. AUNT VOULA, 60's, appears on Maria’s iPhone. AUNT VOULA (ON MARIA’S CELL) I’m on my way, I was at Zumba. Now Gus and Uncle Taki are on a bench.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: We need to find Paris a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE TAKI
dialogues.text: How about Ariana Skoufis’s boy?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Everyone from that island has six toes.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE TAKI
dialogues.text: Let's wait until summer, we’1l check his feet.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BOOTH
dialogues.text: Aunt Voula comes in still talking into her iPad. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: I don’t see you, I don’t see you. I see you. She hangs up, greets Maria, shows her iPad. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Look at this App, 10,000 steps, I met my goal. Where’s Taki? He never answers his phone.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (wryly) ; Why stand when you can sit? Maria points to Gus and Uncle Taki on the bench. Gus and Uncle Taki see their wives looking over at them.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Look tired so they’1l leave us alone. Gus and Uncle Taki slump.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey Angelo, you get my flatscreen

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Oh, I got it right here. Angelo raps Nick in the groin, they laugh and wrestle. Costa grabs his cousin Aristotle and they do the same.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Alright, alright, break it up. They ALL turn to see Ian’s long time friend, MIKE, 40's.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Mike! Hey buddy! You miss working at this place? Mike indicates the school and STUDENTS, shudders to Ian.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: No. Too scary for me. Mike wears a CHICAGO POLICE OFFICER uniform. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry we're late -- Mike and his wife, cousin MARIANTHI, 40's...

dialogues.speaker: MARIANTHI
dialogues.text: -- we picked up Mana-Yiayia. Wait, where is she? They all look around for Mana-Yiayia. Mike lifts a table covering to find: Gus’s mother, MANA- YIAYIA, 90’s. She holds a Tupperware of:

dialogues.speaker: MANA-YIAYIA
dialogues.text: Spanakopita! The family descends on Mana-Yiayia and eats. Aunt Voula hands her iPad to the Northwestern Rep. The wo crowd around Paris.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Take a picture. Nikki moves beside Athena.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Pull my neck back.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Yeah, do mine. The women put their hands on the back of each other’s nec pulling back each other’s neck skin so their faces look younger. Paris is horrified. Toula sees Paris watch STUDENTS walk around her giant fam

dialogues.speaker: CLIFFORD
dialogues.text: Hey, Bennett. Bennett. Paris turns. There he is. And he saw her family. Toula sees this, turns to the family.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: We should go.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Why? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 Ian impatiently indicates the waiting Northwestern Rep.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: So Paris can go to Northwestern.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: That’s right, she’s going to Northwestern. Paris scowls at that decision being made for her.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: If she gets in. The family gasps. Gus and Taki stand.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: If?! The family murmurs. Nick and Angelo quickly step to the R pull him aside:

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (sotto) If my niece wants to come to your school, you’re going to say “welcome,” got it?

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: (sotto) And tuition discount means a box of steaks for you. The Rep looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: None of this is actually up to me. No one sees Paris slip away. Gus steps up.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: She's only coming there if you teach Greek history. Toula grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: Of course we have a Classics program, Greek, Italian- Gus smirks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: The Greeks invented Italy.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: Actually, no.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You Greek?

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: No, sir. I’m a Sephardic Jew.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Then you Greek.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: No, my family is Spanish--

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Alexander the Great went through Spain spreading his seed. You Greek. Some of the family nods. Some look doubtful. Toula cringe

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Gus, it’s not the time.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHWESTERN REP
dialogues.text: And it’s ridiculous. They all start arguing with the Rep and each other.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Hey! No one notices her.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey!! Everyone turns around. Paris holds up four pamphlets.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alabama, Florida, Texas, New York. These are the colleges I’m applying to!! Far, far away from here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everyone is stunned. Toula blurts:

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Why do you want to leave me? Paris’s eyes bug at that. She stalks out. The Family is devastated by the thought of losing Paris. shakes his head to Toula.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Didn't I say, get your daughter a Greek boyfriend? Gus turns back to the Rep.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you, educate yourself! We are all descendants of Alexander the Great! I am for sure!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, you’re not! The family argues. Toula and Ian look miserable. Nick and Angelo threaten the Rep. Mike shows his gun. The Rep turns away. To Mana-Yiayia, offering spanakopita.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. DANCING ZORBA’S - DAY Late February Thaw.

dialogues.speaker: COSTA, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Give me a word, any word and I will show you how the root of that word is Greek!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DANCING ZORBA’S - DAY

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOTLE
dialogues.text: Okay, Chimichanga! In a booth, Costa and Aristotle drink tea and play backgammon. Gus (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COSTA
dialogues.text: Sure. Chimi is from the Greek word keema which means spicy beef and changa is from the Greek word tsanta which means purse. So, meat that is shaped like a purse: chimichanga. There you go!

dialogues.speaker: ARISTOTLE
dialogues.text: There you go. From the next booth, Gus doesn’t look up from his newspap

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: There you go. At the counter, Toula watches Paris buttering garlic brea Nick and Angelo come in, mid-conversation.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Anyway, just meet her, she’s from Holland.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Nah, I don’t speak Hollandaise. Quit setting me up. They see Athena and Nikki through the short order window, motion “hunger” at their mouths as they sit at the counte Nikki and Athena place a plate of sandwiches at the windo Toula passes sandwiches to the men, puts one on a plate, gives it to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Hey... Paris doesn’t look up. Toula indicates herself.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um, just because you don’t want this to be your job when you’re my age, doesn’t mean you have to run off to college in another city. I hope you applied to some local colleges too. Paris looks Toula straight on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Why do parents always say, “dream big”, when they really mean, “but not too big.” Like, “fly little birdie, oh wait, let me hold your wings.” Toula cannot deny this is true. Gus walks by, coughs into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Payback.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: What? Gus covers, jerks a thumb toward the back.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Office. Gus passes Mana-Yiayia running a floor-waxer bigger than

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DANCING ZORBA’S OFFICE - DAY, LATER Toula comes in. As if he’s hiding something, Gus quickly closes a cupboard, limps to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Dad, let me take you back to physical therapy.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I can fix it myself. Gus waves her off, points to a chair, Toula sits.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Please don’t lecture me about my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I’m going to find her a boyfriend, she'll stay in Chicago. Relax, you're getting wrinkles like the dried figs in my village. Toula tries to relax her face. Gus motions to the compute (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Show me how to work that.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You want to learn how to use a computer?!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Yeah. What’s that called where people search for... DNA?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Uh... a crime scene?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: No, where they came from.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Oh. The Find Your Ancestry site? Gus nods. Toula types it in. Gus looks at the site.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Ha! I’m going to prove to your mother that I’m related to Alexander the Great. Don’t tell her. He holds a finger to his lips, shhh, it’s a secret.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: No noooo. You'll have to type in your relatives all the way back to 300 BC. You get frustrated just adding up checks.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Your mother talks to me and I lose count! Show me. Toula exhales. Then, points to the cursor.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Okay, this is called a mouse.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Put your hand on it. Gus covers it completely. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Less. Gus does.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, now look on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Don’t make up words, you confuse me.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Okay. See, on the scree -- uh, computer? That’s your mouse moving. Gus stares. Moves the mouse. Then... sees it. His entire face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I got this.

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: Gus pounds the table, Toula turns from the cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where did it go?!

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You have to press SAVE! Toula tries to help Gus input information.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DAY
dialogues.text: Gus and Ian scream at the computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Quit?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: No quit!!

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DAY
dialogues.text: Gus is inputting numbers Ian is reciting. Of course, Gus gets them all wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER DAY
dialogues.text: Gus is inputting a document’s numbers as Nick sleeps. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 3276 Toula comes in with snacks. Nick wakes up, tries to shove Toula into the chair. Gus never turns around as Nick and Toula wrestle to force each other to stay.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER NIGHT
dialogues.text: The desk lamp glows as Gus works alone. He puts a documen into a dusty tin which once held Greek cookies... sees hi marriage certificate, picks it up. CLOSE-UP: the signature line is empty. Gus is confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OVERHEAD SHOT of the parking lot: Gus’s Cadillac is pa askew with its rear tire up on the curb. The service is over, Gus and Maria walk out with Mana-Yia Aunt Voula, Uncle Taki, Angelo, Athena, Yianni, Nick, Ila their BABY BOY, Nikki, her husband, all the SONS. Toula, Ian and Paris come out. Maria indicates the FAMILY

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: See Paris, you can’t move away, who would you go to church with? This lands on Toula and Ian, Paris doesn’t have an answer Gus points to a GROUP of GREEK BOYS.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Look Paris, husbands. Paris quickly turns away.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I'll be in the car.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I‘1l go with you.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Me too. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (dryly) Of course. Aunt Voula nudges Angelo toward a group of ATTRACTIVE WOM

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Angelo, go pick a wife.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Let it go, Ma. The PRIEST introduces ANNA, 40's.

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: Gus, Maria, we have a new family. Maria shakes Anna’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: How do you like Chicago?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We love it! Da Bears.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: (not getting it) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We’re the Mikoses. I’m Anna, that’s my husband, George-- Gus sees the back of GEORGE, 40’s, chatting to a GROUP.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I am Maria Portokalos this is my husband, Costa. Do you have children?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Do you have a son?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We do! Gus grunts to Uncle Taki.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Meat-eaters. Maria, invite them to the restaurant. Excuse me, I have to go talk to the Priest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gus heads to the Priest who is heading back up the stairs

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Go slow, your hip. As Anna’s husband George gets closer to them... Nikki brightens.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: I know you!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (so proud) Ah, yes, you must recognize my husband George from the channel 7 news. George flashes gorgeous white teeth.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello ladies. Nikki gets excited.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know you! Do the thing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: “Good evening Chicagoland.” George winks. Nikki unzips her top, grins. Gus goes to the church entrance, holds out the certificat and a pen to the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Pater, look at this. Never signed. Will you-- When he sees the unsigned line, the Priest looks alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DANCING ZORBA’S - DAY In the corner booth, Aunt Voula and Uncle Taki lean to Gu

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: You’re not married?! Gus shushes them, looks around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE TAKI
dialogues.text: How can this be?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You know, the war! The village priest didn’t finish seminary, there was no money for anything. I guess he just came back to town and performed the baptisms, funerals, the weddings, and no one knew! Aunt Voula turns to Uncle Taki.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Lucky we got married in Athens. They cross themselves. Uncle Taki picks up the paper -- no signature.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE TAKI
dialogues.text: Our Priest just can’t sign it?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Not allowed.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE TAKI
dialogues.text: What did Maria say?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to tell her, you know how upset she’1l be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: We’re not married?! Maria holds the marriage certificate. WIDEN: Uncle Taki and Aunt Voula see that Toula, Ian, Nic Ilaria, Athena and Yianni are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: No. Maria laughs harder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: We were never married? And we had children?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Yes. Maria loves it.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I’m a hippie! Gus and Uncle Taki frown.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Maria, this is serious, it’s not right.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Who cares! We’re married now by what’s that called? Time served -- Maria is still laughing.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: People will find out. We have to get married.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: (teasing) Yeah Dad, you better get married, you're starting to look old. The room is quiet. Ian discreetly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too soon? Toula leans back.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: The Priest says he can do it, we can go today. Maria stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Today?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Sounds good. Let’s go. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I’m not ready to get married -- Ian pivots back.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: We're married already!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Then why do we need to see the Priest?! Gus looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: What’s going on? Maria gets up, paces. Then... blurts:

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I want you to propose.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: What?! I did.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, not really. You didn’t say it right and it’s been bothering me for 50 years. The family exchanges looks.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: What did I say?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You don’t remember?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: It was a long time ago!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: You said, “I’m going to America, you coming or not?” All the women wince. The men nod, sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE TAKI/YIANNI/NICK
dialogues.text: It's direct./What’s wrong with it?/ Better than me. Ilaria swats Nick. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ILARIA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you said, “I want to put a baby in you.”

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I thought it was romantic.

dialogues.speaker: ILARIA
dialogues.text: And that was the last time you tried to be romantic. Nobody warns you when you get married, the romance is gone, just like that! That lands on Toula and Ian. They can’t look at each othe Aunt Voula sees this reaction between them, takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Can we focus on my parents here?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Ma, what’s wrong? Maria is upset, trying to decipher her feelings.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just don’t want to get married today. Disconsolate, Maria goes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Toula, do something. Toula starts to follow Maria. Aunt Voula stops Toula.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: I’ll talk to her. Everybody out. Everyone avoids eye contact with Gus and quickly disperse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula hurriedly sorts laundry, knocks over a picture. It’ Paris, at four years old. Toula sits on the bed, sighs. Holding a Marshalls bag, Aunt Voula walks in, lays a WHIT LACE DOILY over the back area of an arm chair.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Um, hi Thea. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Just a present from me. I already did your living room.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Ah. Thank you. Now Aunt Voula pulls a small box from the bag, hands it t Toula.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have tweezers, oh with a light! How’s my mom?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: She's not talking to your dad until he proposes. Your dad said she’s always been bossy and he won’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Okay, I’11l talk to them after I make dinner. Toula gets up. Aunt Voula pulls her back down.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: You and your husband look terrible.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Stop trying to fix everything. You baby your parents because you can’t parent your baby anymore. Your generation, you’re super mommy. Then one day you wake up, realize she doesn’t need you, and you forgot how to brush your own hair.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I don’t have time to --

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Text your husband, you're going on a date.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Where? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, do I have to do everything? Aunt Voula pulls a sexy red nightgown from the bag. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) And for afterward, this will help you sleep better. Toula looks at the nightgown, groans. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Satin is slippery, like an eel in --

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Thea, please! That’s the last thing I can think about. I need a shower and wrinkle cream -- Aunt Voula cups Toula’s face, looks her over.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Wrinkles? No, no, wrinkles. Greek don’t creak. Aunt Voula points to the nightgown. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Anyway, you know what Taki likes in bed? Toula covers her ears, makes noises to drown out Aunt Vou AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Confidence! That’s sexy. Okay, I’m done. Toula uncovers her ears. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) And, dress up like a hotel maid, men love morning room service, sunny side up! Toula claps her hands.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Good talk!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Go on your date, don’t worry about anything. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mana-Yiayia and I will stay with Paris. I’11 talk to her, scare her out of moving away from her family. (laughs) I’m kidding. But not really. Anyway, have fun. Laugh, flirt. One rule: don’t fight, which means don’t talk about your daughter. Remember, you were a girlfriend before you were a mother. Toula smiles, doesn’t know what to say. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) You’re welcome. Aunt Voula waves her hand from Toula’s eyebrows to toes. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Shave everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian sits in a booth, DRESSED AND GROOMED LIKE HE’S HAD A MAKEOVER, looking great, and a bit nervous. Toula, also dressed up, hair blown out, makeup on, walks up. They see each other. A moment. It’s nice. Ian stands to pull her chair out.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Quick. Sit down before my wife gets here. Toula laughs. They admiringly look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're... clean.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Your hair....

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I washed it.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You look pretty. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Four hours, five hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: How much?!

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You look so handsome!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Yeah? Thanks. Aunt Voula called me and said, “you used to be handsome, get it together.” I got my nose hairs trimmed. Toula wryly smiles at that.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Ah, who says there’s no romance after marriage? Ian leans in.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Me, too. Ian takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Let’s work on it. Toula smiles softly.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Okay. They open their menus.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Don’t have garlic. You might get lucky tonight. Toula blushes and laughs. A WAITER comes by.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Would you like something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA AND IAN
dialogues.text: Yes!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ian points to a wine on the list. 37 The Waiter goes. They look around. Turn back, smile shyly

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Do you think Paris will go toa college out of state? Toula remembers what Aunt Voula said.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Thea Voula suggested we don’t talk about Paris. How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Um, good. What’d you do?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Worked, found out my parents aren’t married. You?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Your parents are swingers. The Waiter pours their wine. They drink. Smile awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So wait, why can’t we talk about Paris?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Right? I have to!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Okay, how do we keep her from moving away for college?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: We could act like it’s okay with us.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Reverse psychology. Good. How about a letter? Dear Admissions Board: I sure hope you accept my daughter and her twelve piece drum kit.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Add in, “do you have a Student Lounge where she can sell pot?” Toula laughs, Ian laughs. They lock eyes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toula gets emotional.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I’1l do if she goes... Ian takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: C’mon, hon. It’s our one night out in forever. Toula fights to not cry. Ian picks up a menu.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It‘ll be okay. Toula sadly nods.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MILLER CAR/PORTOKALOS STREET
dialogues.text: The radio PLAYS. Ian drives as Toula looks out the window It’s tense; their date didn’t go well. Ian sighs.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: This is why Aunt Voula said don’t talk about Paris.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: But once you’re a parent, what else do you want to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Thea Voula said to remember I was a girlfriend before I was a mother. Ian slowly smiles a bit at that.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, you were my girlfriend. Now Toula slowly smiles a bit. Ian turns the corner. They're on their street. Ian points to the Portokalos fam home in the distance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember when we were dating, how you wouldn't let me drop you off in front in case your parents saw me?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t want you to see the house.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: How could I miss it? Ian pulls over and parks.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We used to park right here. It’s dark. And quiet. Ian looks out the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I remember those good night kisses. Toula looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You do, huh? Ian leans in.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Yes. They kiss. It’s nice. It keeps going. And going. Really going. The MUSIC swells. And then -- a LIGHT shines into the car.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Toula and Ian cover themselves, shield their eyes. Gus shines a flashlight into the car.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing, we're going.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Everything's okay. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ian struggles to dress himself, Gus realizes what's happening.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You don’t have a house to do that?! Just then, Paris, Aunt Voula and Maria, walking the old L Socrates, round the corner. They see Gus.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Gus, what’s wrong? Aunt Voula and Maria run up, realize it’s Toula and Ian, to push Gus’s flashlight away. AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) Gus! Paris realizes it’s her parents.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (nuh-uh) Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Parents deserve a sex life.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Said no one, ever.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: We're just talking. By the way Paris, we think you should go to college out of state. Toula nods her head as hard as she can.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What is that, reverse psychology?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: That never works.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: That never works.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: That never works. The nosy/cranky neighbor Mrs. White, walking her dog, see the commotion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITE
dialogues.text: What’s going on, I’m calling the cops.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay, Mrs. White, everything is okay. Socrates starts barking at Mrs. White.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITE
dialogues.text: Stop that, quiet!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: He doesn’t speak English. (in soothing Greek to the dog, subtitled) Bite her tomorrow. The Portokalos dog immediately sits. Mrs. White suspiciously looks at them all as she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITE
dialogues.text: I have pepper spray. Gus turns back to Ian.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Ian Miller, in the street?! It’s not decent!! Maria turns on Gus, furious.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: What’s the problem? At least they're married.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Maria....

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Don’t Maria me. We’re not married. Paris’s jaw drops. MARIA (CONT’D) You want decency? Tonight, you sleep in another room. Maria takes the dog toward the house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Fine!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No fine! Neighborhood lights go on. Gus follows Maria in. Aunt Voula leads Paris to the Miller house.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Uh, can I just ask....

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Yes dear, your grandparents are living in sin. Your Pappou won't propose-—

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I don’t get why Yiayia needs that--

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Because you’re not a woman who has lived with Pappou for 50 years. SFX: A door slams inside the Portokalos house. Inside the car, Ian and Toula look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I have to fix this. Smiling, Ian moves in.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Right, right. Anyway, where were we? Toula pushes him away, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: We can’t.... They go back to making out. From the dark Miller yard, Mana-Yiayia runs by, wearing t red nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus sulks. A PHYSICAL THERAPIST attaches weights to Gus’s ankles.

dialogues.speaker: PHYSICAL THERAPIST
dialogues.text: You're late today.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: (mumbles ) My wife wouldn’t drive me.

dialogues.speaker: PHYSICAL THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PHYSICAL THERAPIST
dialogues.text: Lift these, I'll be back. Gus lifts them to impress her. As soon as she’s out of sight, Gus and the OTHER MEN stop working. A swarthy man, KAVEH, 70's, sits on the table beside Gus.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You Greek?

dialogues.speaker: KAVEH
dialogues.text: Iranian.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: So, Persian? Kaveh nods.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In 334 BC, Alexander the Great conquered the Persian Army and occupied the east. You are so Greek, we're probably related. Insulted, Kaveh puffs up.

dialogues.speaker: KAVEH
dialogues.text: We had civilizations in Persia 3000 years before you Greeks discovered rocks. Gus is stunned. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: The Greeks gave the world philosophy, democracy--

dialogues.speaker: KAVEH
dialogues.text: In 2500 BC, we already had instruments that measured weight and money! A Chinese man, PIM, 70's, chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: PIM
dialogues.text: The Chinese gave the world paper and tea and medicine! Another man, BAIRD, 70'S, chimes in with a Scottish accen

dialogues.speaker: BAIRD
dialogues.text: Without Scotland’s Alexander Fleming, the world wouldn’t have penicillin!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Soon I’m going to have proof that I am a direct descendant of Alexander the Great! The others now laugh HARD at Gus. The Physical Therapist comes back, they lift their leg weights. Gus sulks.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DANCING ZORBA’S - DAY From the counter, Toula watches as Gus still sulks in his corner booth. Uncle Taki listens. Gus looks

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I sleep with the dog. She won’t give me my pills in the morning, she won’t clean --

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE TAKI
dialogues.text: Anarchy. over at a table near the counter: Maria whispers with Aunt Voula. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Why can’t he just propose?!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Because he’s stubborn! Aunt Voula looks back, sees Gus and Uncle Taki looking at them.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: He’s looking, act like you’re having fun. 1-2-3, now. Maria and Aunt Voula throw their heads back, fake-laugh. Nick, Nikki and Angelo watch and shake their heads. Toula brightens as she sees Ian come in, with Paris close behind.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Reporting for my garlic bread shift, woo hoo, it’s so fun, kill me. So many other things I could be doing in my Senior year-- Toula hands the bowl she’s been eating from to Paris, who takes it, eats and trudges away.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Like thinking about Prom....

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: (mouth full) Nah, I’m not going to that. Paris sits near Nick and Angelo, who dip their spoons int her bowl. Toula hands a coffee to Ian.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Did you check the mail?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Nothing from colleges yet.... Toula is worried. Ian gently puts a strand of hair behind Toula’s ear. That makes her breath catch.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, remember when you asked me on a dinner date? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: (smiling) Kinda.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: How about another date, tonight?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: How about yeah. Ian leans in further.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (suggestively) I cleaned the car.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Ooh... The door opens again -- It’s George, the attractive newscaster they met at church

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hi! The family is excited to see George again.

dialogues.speaker: CORNER BOOTH
dialogues.text: Gus sees it’s George and perks up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My wife and son are in the car, is this a good time for a visit?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Yes!! George ducks out. Gus claps his hands to Uncle Taki.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He has a son for Paris. Did you see the hair on that Greek god?! I’m going to fix everything, Paris will stay in Chicago, and then-- (full of himself now) -- that woman can propose to me! Uncle Taki grins as Gus starts to slide out of the booth. Gus walks to the front, waving over Paris. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paris, wipe your face. Everyone come, I have a surprise. Uncle Taki, Nick, Nikki and Angelo quickly join. Suddenly, Toula gets it.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Oh! No no. It’s a set-up. Before Paris can protest:

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Every Greek girl should have a Greek boyfriend and I found you one! Toula sees Maria and Voula stand and join, so she and Ian quickly head over, resulting in an anticipatory family gr behind Paris.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Hello! Anna and George come in with their son Theodore. He’s sev A pause. Each family member has a different expression. Paris is delighted with how uncomfortable her family is.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Hey buddy, we’re getting married! Everyone is confused.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You said you had a son for our granddaughter--

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, he didn’t! You don’t listen! Anna and George understand, and laugh it off. Paris gestures to Theodore to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: C’mon, you can help me butter garlic bread. Theodore winks at his dad (who winks back) and heads off Paris. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paris gives Toula and Ian the stink-eye as she passes the they can’t win. Gus steps in front of Maria, to gesture to the nearest ta

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Anyway, welcome to my restaurant! Maria looks sharply to Gus as George and Anna sit.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Our restaurant! Anna, George and CUSTOMERS look up. Gus tight-smiles back

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: It’s in my name. Which makes you my employee.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Then I want back pay for 50 years of overtime. Gus and Maria glare at each other. TIan leans in to Toula

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: What? We can’t leave now- Trying to distract them from the argument, Aunt Voula lea in to Anna and George.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: All my life, I wanted to be a newscaster, but I have a dry mouth. When I went through puberty, my tongue swelled up like a tree root. It’s still puffy, look --

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t want to. Aunt Voula holds her mouth open. Anna and George peer in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That’s a big tongue. Toula doesn’t see exasperated Ian leaving. Gus snaps his fingers at Maria. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Employee! Bring menus.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Get them yourself! The others are shocked and uneasy. MARIA (CONT’D) (sarcastic) Oh no, I was rude to the boss, I hope I don’t get fired! Maria storms off and slams the door. Toula looks queasy. Then sees Ian is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Maria! Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus limps in, stares at the washer. His clothes are piled high in a basket, with a note: “Your employee is on strik

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DANCING ZORBA’S - EVENING The restaurant is empty. Toula gathers her things, checks her cell -- no messages -- makes a call.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Leave a message.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Me again. Um. My dad went home -- his hip, you know -- so I had to... ah, you don’t want to hear... okay, I’m on my way. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toula sighs, turns off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MILLER CAR
dialogues.text: Toula drives, she’s tired, and worried about Ian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula walks from the car into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula is relieved to find Ian sleeping. As he snores, Tou smiles to herself, leans close to kiss him. The house phone rings. Ian opens his eyes, Toula is way too close. He screams. S screams. They scramble for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hello? Hi Maria. He looks at Toula.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes. Ian hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your dad-- Toula grabs her throat.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s okay. He’s stuck in the bathtub. Your mom can’t lift him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVERHEAD SHOT: Toula, Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni, in various states of undress, run from separate houses and u the Portokalos family driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula, Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni run up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula, Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni run in: Maria points, Nick runs past her and into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What’s up, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Hello Nicko! Nick immediately comes out, pale.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Ma, you couldn’t put some clothes on him?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: If I could, I wouldn’t need you.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: YIANNI
dialogues.text: Did he fall?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No, it’s that hip. It’s locked. Gus yells from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: I’m fine! Maria back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No fine! Do your physical therapy like the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: How long has he been in that tub? Maria shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: A few hours. He wouldn’t let me call you. So, I let the water go cold. The sleeping dog at her feet, in the armchair, Mana-Yiayi does embroidery and laughs at the dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Maria, will you please drain the tub--

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: -- and put a towel over him? Maria nods and goes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: (to Toula) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can’t unsee that.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Just be quiet. As Maria argues with Gus, the men look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Do we call an ambulance? Toula and Nick shake their heads at Ian.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’ll make him feel old.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: He’d never forgive you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, you’d call. And we’d have to tell him you called.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: C'mon, how do we do this?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: When I was in the kitchen, to season a roast, we had to get our hands under it and turn it over. Toula realizes what he is suggesting and grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Sure, I flipped a dead body once -- Ian opens drawers, cupboards.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Surely the man has a pair of shorts! Maria comes out, shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Okay, I put a towel over his private area --

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: A big one. Maria rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes, yes Gus, a big one. She shakes her head to everyone. Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni look at each other -- they h to do this.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So, what’s our plan again?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We roll him over -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: -- then he’s on his hands and knees and up.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: That will work. The men nod, head toward the bathroom with Ian trailing.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Wait, how would that work? Nick ignores Ian, turns back and looks at the other men.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: IAN/YIANNI/ANGELO
dialogues.text: Nuh uh./No./God no. Nick opens the door and they head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus sits in the tub. Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni run in:

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Why are your eyes closed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RED and BLUE LIGHTS illuminate houses. An AMBULANCE and a FIRE TRUCK are in front of the Portokalos family home.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BASE OF THE DRIVEWAY/ON THE SIDEWALK
dialogues.text: SEVERAL NEIGHBORS watch the drama. The cranky neighbor, M White, walks up, sees the yellow tape.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITE
dialogues.text: I always knew there’d be a murder here. Mike pulls up in his squad car, goes into the house.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ian, Nick, Angelo and Yianni sit on the ambulance back fender. They shudder, huddled in blankets, all being trea for cuts, bruises and sprains. Aunt Voula appears with a bottle of Metaxa.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: This will take away your pain. Twice I drank it and gave birth without drugs. Aunt Voula leans in to the AMBULANCE ATTENDANT: AUNT VOULA (CONT’D) One of my ovaries never put out an egg. Not one. The other one would spit out two a month. I could feel it, right here. Ping, ping. But the left ovary? Nothing. It was closed, like a stuck zipper.... Toula rubs Ian’s shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You okay? Ian blinks and opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: I still see it. They share the bottle, sipping Metaxa.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Does this count as a date? Ian gives her a wry smile, but shakes his head, no. Suddenly, Toula holds her arms out to him.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- Then--

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Toula!

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Coming! Toula and Ian sigh and she runs toward the house. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she passes, Toula notices the neighbors, including Mar and Edie, the Volunteer Committee moms, watching it all.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: Here comes a stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITE
dialogues.text: Ah. I’m sure the grandma finally went.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What was she, a hundred and twenty?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. WHITE
dialogues.text: Must have slept in pickle juice. Mrs. White turns, sees Mana-Yiayia right beside her and j as if she’s seen a ghost. Mana-Yiayia doesn’t bat an eye.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Gus is wheeled out to the ambulance in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: I’m fine! Maria follows.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No fine! Toula go to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: You're not coming?!

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No. Because guess why? Family members only. That means children and wife. If you had one! The Neighbors murmur at this salacious morsel. Marge and Edie look at each other with glee.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: What? Edie giggles. The ATTENDANTS push Gus’s stretcher down the driveway. Gus’s POV: Maria gets smaller and smaller. And smaller. Suddenly, Gus sits up and cries out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Maria, please, will you marry me?! The entire FAMILY and NEIGHBORHOOD wait. Maria pauses, then satisfied, nods once.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes, okay, I’ll marry you. Toula, take me to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I’ll get my car. Toula heads down the driveway, and sees the neighbors on sidewalk, whispering.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: «+. such a weird family.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Odd people. Toula shakes her head but ignores them. Toula now sees: Paris is in the Miller driveway... she he Angry, Toula turns back to the neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: What? Marge and Edie look up, caught, but not chagrined.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: You mean pardon?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: No, I mean, what. As in what is wrong with you? You’re standing on our lawn making fun of my family? Oh we're so weird, oh we smell like burnt oregano and feta cheese. I got it. But that’s my dad going into that ambulance, my dad -- Toula fights back tears. Paris steps forward, puts her ar around her mom.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Good night everyone. The Neighbors quickly disperse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Paris slowly walks her mom to their driveway.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘1l come to the hospital too. Toula puts a hand on her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black Cadillac backs out of the Portokalos driveway, stops at the Miller home. Toula and Paris hurry out.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: I/E. GUS'S CADILLAC/NICK’S HOUSE - DAY, CONTINUOUS Maria is driving, tired and still mad. Toula rubs her eye There’s a knock on Maria’s window: it’s Marge and Edie. Toula looks back at Paris. Maria opens the window.

dialogues.speaker: MARGE
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: EDIE
dialogues.text: How’s your husband?

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: He’ll live. So I can kill him. Toula is surprised at the women’s empathy. Maria drives.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Basically Mom told them to suck it. Toula realizes she did.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Good. Paris, you come from a long line of strong women.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Which means, you can choose your own seven-year-old boyfriend. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toula sees that for the first time in a long time, Paris smiles at something she said.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: So, Yiayia, are you and Pappou really going to get married now? Now Maria grins.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Yes, and this time, I’m doing it right!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A GREEK SINGER sings WHITE WEDDING over.... A MONTAGE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding out her brochure, a CHIC WEDDING PLANNER walks in smiling. Then she glares at: PULL BACK: Maria, Aunt Voula and Athena going through the racks of creamy, dreamy dresses. In the front window Mana-Yiayia poses in a wedding dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wedding Planner presents cream and white flowers. Tou and Nikki see Maria reach for her choice - a giant bouque orange birds of paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wedding Planner shows a demure cake and is shocked wh Maria, Athena and Nikki love a garish cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria excitedly points to a sample of a Bride and a Groom faces floating in two roses. The Wedding Planner face pal herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Wedding Planner shows an elegant black limousine. She turns to find Maria loving a GIANT PINK LIMO VAN. Inside car, Athena and Nikki have powdered sugar under their nos as they eat kourambiedes. Maria hands her phone to the Wedding Planner.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Take a picture.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: One, two, three, pull! Maria and Aunt Voula pull each other’s neck skin. FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IT’S ALMOST SPRING. Ian walks from his car to the house mailbox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula takes a roast chicken from the oven. Ian comes in - bit shaken -- with mail from VARIOUS COLLEGES.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Paris? Paris comes in, sees the look on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: You open them. Ian tears envelopes, reads the letters, looks up, emotion (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Toula Paris She's Paris Toula

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Well, it looks like a choice between Northwestern... (pointedly) .+. right here in Chicago. And uh, NYU in New York. and Ian grab Paris into a three-way hug.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: We are so proud of you!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So proud! And, uh... the question is, where do you want to go to college? is proud of herself. Her expression turns fearful. not ready to go away. She thinks, then looks up.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I'll stay here in Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: (faux casual) Okay, if that’s what you want. is relieved. They hug again. Behind Paris’s head, and Ian celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. DANCING ZORBA’S OFFICE - DAY, LATER Toula runs in.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Dad, did you hear the news, Paris is staying!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: She found a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Dad--

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Very good news, Toula!

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Yup! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 Gus shows a certified mail receipt to: Find Your Ancestry Gus Gus Gus Gus hip

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: Oh, look what I mailed today.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You completed the application!

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: By myself. It was hard to remember every name and date--

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: (gently) You could have called Theo Panos in Greece. grumbles.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: So my brother can tell me what I’m doing is stupid. is standing without a cane. It rests on the wall. snorts.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Your physical therapy is working.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: It’s not that therapy. I fixed it myself. pulls out a bottle of Windex, lifts his shirt, sprays his area, stretches, grins at Toula.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You're happy the wedding is on, huh?

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: But Toula, I can’t afford the wedding your mother wants! That’s not news to Toula, she nods.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: We could give you money.

dialogues.speaker: GUS
dialogues.text: No! You need it for college. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gus rubs his chest from the anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: GUS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t sleep without your mother snoring! (gets serious) You're married, you know what it’s like to have that person there, right beside you. In every way. You walk through your life, seeing your shadow as two people. You know you can reach out in the night and that person is there. And then they’re not... because they make you stay on the couch until a Priest says it’s okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the kitchen table, Paris and Mana-Yiayia dip koulouria into milk.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: Mana-Yiayia, I’m going to stay home for college. Mana-Yiayia smiles. They eat.

dialogues.speaker: PARIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's good, right? It’s what I want. Mana-Yiayia stops chewing, looks at Paris.

dialogues.speaker: MANA-YIAYIA
dialogues.text: But is not. Mana-Yiayia smiles gently. SFX: a front door slams. Paris and Mana-Yiayia look up: Maria comes in, distraught.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: The Wedding Planner fired me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula paces. Ian rushes in from work.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: So now they’re not getting married?!

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I have to fix this. Ian takes a moment. Then --

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: When do you think you can fix us? Toula looks up quickly.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: You're always running in and out of here, cooking something, volunteering somewhere. It’s like you avoid being alone with me--

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: But you just explained why I’m not here.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Look, it’s my fault too; we're busy. But Toula, we’ve been trying to have a date, just another dinner alone. And it’s impossible. Your family pulls at you--

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: That’s what family does--

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: No, that’s what your family does, my family doesn’t pull me.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Well, maybe they do but you don’t notice-- Toula lays her head on Ian’s chest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please. Help me get my parents married. They hold each other. It’s sweet.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: All right. Who can we ask? They look at each other. And grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toula opens the front door and Aunt Voula enters.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: I’m here! Toula starts to shut the door, but it opens. The ENTIRE FAMILY (except Maria and Gus) comes thundering

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: You called the family?!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Of course. Ian is surprised as RODNEY AND HARRIET, 70's, arrive. AUNT FREIDA, 60’s, announces in her always-loud voice.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FREIDA
dialogues.text: Rodney and Harry are here!

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom and Dad.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY AND HARRIET
dialogues.text: Yiasas, Yiasas everyone!

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: You got any of that moussaka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family are squashed on the couch, chairs, etc. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Tell your problem.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Uh, okay...

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Toula’s parents are not married. No one blinks.

dialogues.speaker: IAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, you all know?

dialogues.speaker: MARIANTHI
dialogues.text: Please. Aunt Freida shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FREIDA
dialogues.text: Telephone, telegram, tell-a-Greek.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: The wedding planner quit! No one blinks again.

dialogues.speaker: TOULA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know that too?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FREIDA
dialogues.text: What are you, new? JENNIE, 30's, nods.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIE
dialogues.text: Of course we know.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: We know everything.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: I tweeted it.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Aunt Voula we were hoping you could talk to Maria?

dialogues.speaker: ATHENA
dialogues.text: Convince her to just go to the church and get it done. 66 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The AUNTS Ian and Toula look at each other. (2)

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: Please. and UNCLES look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT FREIDA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Because my dad will lose it.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: No, why convince them to just “get it done”?

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Look, weddings are expensive--

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: But what was with hiring a wedding planner?

dialogues.speaker: TOULA
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANTHI
dialogues.text: Yeah, we've all had weddings --

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Except Angelo--

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: We're not talking about me! Nikki jumps in. 67 Aunt Voula raises an eyebrow to Nikki: leave it alone.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: I’m sayin’ -- you don’t need a caterer.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIE
dialogues.text: We all cook.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Some of us better than others.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANTHI
dialogues.text: Don’t start-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: Your diples are dry, accept it. Marianthi turns to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: MARIANTHI
dialogues.text: Mike, can you taser her?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Only once per relative, you know my rule.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIE
dialogues.text: We'll have the reception at their house!

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: I’1l do the hair!

dialogues.speaker: AUNT VOULA
dialogues.text: Angelo can get Maria a dress!

dialogues.speaker: ANGELO
dialogues.text: Yeah! My business partner was in a band, there were tuxedos --

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: I can do an emailed invitation!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
